byline.original: By ERIC LIPTON and LIZ MOYER

abstract: Congressional lawmakers, led by Sen Harry Reid, included 54 words in tax and spending bill at behest of lobbyists to preserve loophole that accounts for $1 billion in lost revenue; loophole, which allows real estate to be placed in trusts and avoid capital gain taxes, was of particular interests to hotel, restaurant and gambling industries as well as investors; move hints at power lobbyists hold as Congress hashes out large bills in little time.
lead_paragraph: Lobbyists recently swooped in to add 54 words to a tax and spending bill of more than 2,000 pages that temporarily preserved a loophole sought by the hotel, restaurant and gambling industries, and billionaire Wall Street investors.

headline.main: Hospitality and Gambling Interests Delay Closing of Billion-Dollar Tax Loophole
headline.print_headline: Lobbyists Shield a Tax Loophole Worth $1 Billion

snippet: Lobbyists recently swooped in to add 54 words to a tax and spending bill of more than 2,000 pages that temporarily preserved a loophole sought by the hotel, restaurant and gambling industries, and billionaire Wall Street investors.
